text.p: Times Square, once a seedy part of Manhattan that attracted prostitutes and drug addicts, is now home to an attraction for family entertainment: a renovated New Amsterdam theatre.
Walt Disney Co., which leases the 94-year-old theatre, outlined the first three shows to appear on its stage since undergoing a $34 million renovation.

"King David," billed as "concert event," is the inaugural show, premiering May 18. From June 15-26, "Hercules," will appear at the theatre. In the fall, the stage version of the animated film, "Lion King," is to appear.
Disney Chairman Michael Eisner said at a news conference that he recently walked down 42nd Street and was struck by how the area had changed since the days when he grew up in New York.
"I went to movies in this theatre, some of which could not appear on Disney today," Eisner said.
